Graphical abstract Supported Cu catalysts are found to be active in gas phase transfer hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde into hydrocinnamaldehyde. Cu/SiO2 catalyst is superior in conversion of α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds into saturated carbonyl compounds. This work aims to produce hydrocinnamaldehyde via selective CC bond hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde via transfer hydrogenation catalyzed by supported Cu catalysts. The catalytic activity and characterization results demonstrated that conversion of cinnamaldehyde and selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde is an integrated result of active Cu metal surface area and nature of support material. In the case of Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde was linearly dependent on the active Cu metal surface area. A maximum rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde 167.82 μmol.g−1.s-1 was obtained at an active Cu metal surface area of 6.1 m2.gcat -1 over 20 wt. % Cu/SiO2 catalyst. While in the case of other supported Cu catalysts (Cu/MgO, Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/γ-Al2O3) along with the active Cu metal surface area, the surface acidity and basicity governed the selectivity of hydrocinnamaldehyde. The rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde followed the trend Cu/SiO2 >Cu/Al2O3 >Cu/MgO > Cu/ZrO2. Unlike Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the competitive adsorption of CC and CO bonds over these (Al2O3, MgO and ZrO2) supported Cu catalysts altered the selectivity of hydrocinnamaldehyde. Cu/SiO2 catalyst was superior in selective CC hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds via transfer hydrogenation. Cyclohexenone, isophorone and crotonaldehyde were selectively converted into their saturated carbonyl compounds. Keywords α, β- unsaturated carbonyl compound Cinnamaldehyde Hydrocinnamaldehyde Cu/SiO2 Hydrogenation Introduction The chemo selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated carbonyls to saturated carbonyls such as cinnamaldehyde (CALD) to hydrocinnamaldehyde (HCALD) is an imperative transformation in both the academic and industrial research. Saturated carbonyl compounds are versatile chemicals for biological applications. HCALD is a key chemical intermediate in synthesis of drugs for AIDS and in other pharmaceuticals [1–5]. Being a multifunctional molecule, selective hydrogenation of CALD to a particular product is quite complex [6]. Most of the hydrogenations are targeted for the saturation of CO rather than the hydrogenation of thermodynamically favorable CC bond. However, the selective hydrogenation of CC in α, β-unsaturated carbonyls can only produce saturated carbonyls from unsaturated ones. Some of the researchers have been reported the selective hydrogenation of CC bond of CALD to produce HCALD over noble metal and/or bimetallic catalytic systems. Among the noble metals, Pd is the most active one in selective hydrogenation of CC of α, β-unsaturated carbonyls. Zhang et al. developed homogeneous PdCl2–0.5Co(OAc)2–PPh3 catalyst assisted by NaBH4 for hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD [7]. Cuong et al. reported that the Pd supported on carbon nano fibers exhibited better activity in HCALD synthesis than Pd/Charcoal due to the absence of microporosity in carbon nanofibers [8]. Later, the same group reported deposition of Pd nanoparticles on multi walled carbon nano tubes (MWCNT) and proposed that strong metal support interactions and absence of micropores are responsible for the higher selectivity to CC bond [9]. Recently, Pedro et al. have examined Pd decorated composite material of MWCNT and activated carbon for selective hydrogenation of CALD under pressurized H2 conditions [10]. Pd supported on modified carbon such as N-doped mesoporous and hierarchically porous carbon have resulted much more selectivity towards HCALD than their activated carbon catalysts [11,12]. Other supported Pd catalysts like Pd/γ-Al2O3 [13], Pd/C [14], Pd/La2O2CO3 [15], Pd/PPh2-PEGPIILP [16] and Pd/ZIF-8 [17] also have successfully established for hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD. In addition, Pt based catalysts are also active for synthesis of HCALD from CALD. The majority of Pt catalytic systems are bimetallic catalytic systems which are much more selective than their respective monometallic catalytic systems. For instance, Pt–Ni/Carbon nanotubes [18], Pt-Ni/ZrO2 [19], Pt-Au/SiO2 [20] and Pt-Ru/Carbon nanofibers [21] are more selective than their corresponding monometallic counterparts. Apart from noble metal catalysts, Ni is also selective for CC hydrogenation in CALD.Linet.al. reported the promotional effect of Ir in Ni/TiO2 for selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD at 20 bar H2 pressure [22]. NiP/SiO2 [23], Ni/AC [24] catalysts are successfully optimized for the HCALD synthesis under pressurized H2 in batch processes. Some of the researchers have investigated bimetallic Cu catalysts for hydrogenation of CALD. Ni-Cu/SiO2 [25], Cu-Mg-Al [26], Au–Cu/CeO2 [27] catalysts are found to be selective for synthesis of HCALD. Although afore mentioned catalytic systems are selective for HCALD synthesis, there are difficulties to be eliminated. Most of them are cost expensive noble metal catalytic systems, operated at harsh reaction conditions (pressurized with H2) and in batch processes need of further steps to separate product and catalyst. Hence, there is a room for exploration of non-noble metal catalytic systems for selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD in continuous process under transfer hydrogenation conditions. It is reported that Cu based catalytic systems are active in transferring hydrogen from alcohols to carbonyls. Recently, María et al. stated that Cu-Mg-Al is effectively hydrogenated furfural to furfuryl alcohol via transfer of hydrogen from isopropanol [28]. Long et al. investigated role of support in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation over Cu/Al2O3 and reported that amount and acid/base properties influence the dehydrogenation of alcohol [29]. Earlier our group has patented the coupling of endothermic dehydrogenation of Cyclohexanol with exothermic hydrogenation of furfural in a hydrogen economy approach over supported Cu catalysts in continuous process [30,31]. Cu is highly active metal to dehydrogenate alcohol and subsequent transfer of the hydrogen to unsaturated group in other molecule [32,33]. With these preliminary understandings and on continuation of our research work in selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated carbonyls [34,35], the present work has been undertaken to develop a non-noble metal Cu based catalytic system for selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD via transfer hydrogenation in continuous process (Scheme 1 ). There are reports on the transfer hydrogenation of CALD over Zr based and other metal oxide catalytic systems. But they produce cinnamyl alcohol through CO reduction via Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction mechanism without disturbing CC of CALD [36,37]. To the best of our knowledge, still there are no reports regarding synthesis of HCALD from CALD via transfer hydrogenation of CC in continuous process. The content of present study involves investigation on the role of support in supported Cu catalysts with wide range of acidic and basic oxides. Secondly correlation of Cu active metal surface area with the catalytic activity and examination of this protocol on other α, β-unsaturated carbonyls. Besides these, the reaction parameters such as molar ratio of CALD to isopropanol, reaction temperature, WHSV (Weight Hourly Space Velocity) etc. are optimized. Experimental Catalyst preparation SiO2 is purchased from M/s. Sigma Aldrich USA and γ-Al2O3 from M/s. Sudchemi, India. Cu/SiO2 catalysts with various loadings of Cu (5, 10, 20 and 30 wt %) were prepared by wet impregnation method using Cu (NO3)2. 3H2O (M/s. Sigma Aldrich USA) as Cu precursor. In a typical method, an aqueous solution containing requisite amount of Cu precursor was added to SiO2 and the mixture was allowed to dry with continuous stirring. The solid was dried in hot oven at 100 °C for 12 h and then it was calcined in static air at 450 °C for 4 h. Some portion of the solid samples was reduced in H2 flow at 280 °C for 3 h. The resultant samples were labeled as xCu/SiO2 where x represents weight percentage of Cu. In similar fashion, 20Cu/MgO, 20Cu/ZrO2 and 20Cu/γ-Al2O3 were prepared. MgO and ZrO2 were prepared by precipitation method using Mg (NO3)2 6H2O and ZrOCl2.8H2O as precursors respectively. Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on an UltimaIV (M/s. Rigaku Corporation, Japan) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA equipped with nickel-filtered Cu K radiation (λ=1.54056 Å). The detailed catalyst characterization procedures are presented in Electron supplementary Information. Activity test The chemo-selective hydrogenation of CALD was performed in a fixed bed down flow reactor (14 mm id 300 mm length) at atmospheric conditions. In a typical reaction, 0.5 g of the catalyst was mixed with equal amount of quartz particles and it was secured between two quartz plug wool. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in flow of H2 (30 mL/min) at 280 °C for 3 h. Then the reaction temperature was fixed and the carrier flow is switched to N2 (30 mL/min). The liquid feed with required mole ratio of CALD and isopropanol by syringe feed pump (M/s. B. Braun, Germany). The product mixture is collected in ice cold trap and analyzed by FID equipped GC-7820 A (M/s. Agilent Technologies) with HP–5 capillary column (30 m ×0.53 mm ×5.0 μm) and confirmed by GC–MS, QP-2010 (M/s. Shimadzu Instruments, Japan) with EB–5 MS capillary column (30 m ×0.25 mm ×0.25 μm). Results and discussion In order to choose the optimum copper loading over SiO2, Cu/SiO2 catalysts were subjected to chemo selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD and the results were presented in Fig. ES 1. At 5 wt% of copper loading the conversion of CALD is 60% and selectivity to HCALD is 100%. With increase in copper loading the conversion of CALD is also increased and complete conversion of CALD is obtained at 20 wt% copper loading. Beyond this copper loading, the conversion of CALD is declined. The decline in conversion of CALD at copper loadings higher than 20 wt% is may be due to the increase in copper particles size in 30Cu/SiO2 catalyst. It is interesting to mention that the selectivity to HCALD in all the cases is 100%. This demonstrates the excellence of Cu/SiO2 catalysts in H2-free chemo selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD. The chemo selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD was examined over various supported Cu catalysts and results were shown in Table 1 . The schematic representation of hydrogenation of CALD is shown in Scheme 1. The catalytic activity of various Cu/SiO2 catalysts was presented and discussed in Electronic Supplementary Information. Among the supported Cu catalysts, 20Cu/SiO2 exhibited better catalytic performance with respect to CALD conversion and HCALD selectivity. The conversion of CALD in all the supported Cu catalysts is above 70%, but a diverse product distribution is noticed except with 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst. 20Cu/MgO, 20Cu/ZrO2 and 20Cu/Al2O3 catalysts showed moderate selectivity of HCALD 53.51, 43.46 and 61.17% respectively. In these catalysts, other products such as cinnamyl alcohol (CAOL), allyl benzene (AB), propyl benzene (PB) and others are formed at the expense of HCALD selectivity. The rate of formation of HCALD is higher (167.82 μmol.g−1.s−1) with 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst than other supported catalysts. The rate of formation of HCALD over these supported catalysts is in the order: 20Cu/SiO2 > 20Cu/Al2O3 > 20Cu/MgO > 20Cu/ZrO2. The results show discrepancy in the catalytic performance of supported Cu catalysts is presumably due to the unified effects of active Cu metal dispersion and nature of support. The powder XRD patterns of reduced samples of supported Cu catalysts were presented in Fig. 1 . It could be observed from the Fig.1; all the XRD patterns show diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 43.5, 50.6 and 74.3° manifest the presence of metallic Cu which is in agreement with JCPDS-04836. No other Cu phases were observed from the XRD analysis. The average crystallite sizes of metallic Cu was estimated by Scherer’s equation and presented in Table 1. For 20Cu/MgO sample, the diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 36.8, 42.7, 62.2 and 78.5° confirm the presence of MgO crystalline phase (JCPDS No. 4-829). The diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 24.2, 28.1, 31.4, 34.2 and 55.3° indicate the presence of monoclinic ZrO2 phase (JCPDS- 37–1484). The diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 46.1 and 66.8° corresponds to the crystalline phase of γ-Al2O3. Fig.ES2 shows the powder XRD patterns of reduced Cu/SiO2 catalysts. In all the catalysts the broad diffraction signal at around 2θ of 22° represents the amorphous silica. The diffraction peaks at around 2θ of 43.5, 50.5 and 74.3° indicates the presence of metallic Cu in agreement with JCPDS-0483. The reducibility of copper oxide species in calcined supported copper catalysts was investigated by temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) with H2/Ar mixture gas a probe gas and corresponding results were presented in Fig. 2 . Except 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst, other supported Cu catalysts show a single stage reduction of CuO species. 20Cu/ZrO2, 20Cu/MgO and 20Cu/Al2O3 catalysts show reduction of CuO species at Tmax in between 288–329 °C. It represents a single stage reduction of CuO species to Cu (0) i.e., CuO + H2→Cu + H2O. For 20Cu/MgO catalyst, the shift in reduction temperature to higher values may be attributed to increased metal support interactions between Cu and MgO through defect sites present in MgO [38]. The low temperature reduction of copper oxide in 20Cu/SiO2 and 20Cu/Al2O3 catalysts represents the high reducibility of copper oxide over SiO2 and Al2O3 supports [39]. H2-TPR profile of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst shows two reduction peaks at Tmax of 210 °C and 289 °C. The low reduction temperature peak is attributed to well-dispersed CuO particles and the high reduction temperature peak is assigned to presence of bulk CuO species [40,41]. The reducible features of calcined SiO2 supported catalysts are evaluated by H2-TPR and corresponding profiles were presented in Fig. ES3. All the silica supported copper catalysts shows two stage reduction of CuO species to Cu (0). It could be observed that there is a slight shift in the first Tmax towards high temperature. It indicates the formation large CuO crystallites with increase in copper loading. The physicochemical characteristics of the supported Cu catalysts were reported in Table 2 . The physico chemical features of Cu/SiO2 catalysts were presented in Table ES1. BET-surface areas of Cu/SiO2 catalysts are decreasing with increase in copper loading. In the same trend the dispersion of copper metal is decreased. The active copper metal surface area is increased with copper loading up to 20 wt% and reaches a maximum of 6.1 m2.g.cat−1. Further increase in copper loading to 30 wt% results decrease in active copper metal surface area may be due to the increase in the copper particles size. A correlation between the active Cu metal surface area (SCu) and rate of formation of HCALD with copper loading was made and presented in Fig. 3 . The rate of formation of HCALD is strongly influenced by the active Cu metal surface area of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts. A maximum rate of formation of HCALD (167.82 μmol.g−1.s−1) is obtained at an active Cu metal surface area of 6.1 m2.g.cat−1. The active Cu metal surface area and rate of formation of HCALD are linearly dependent on copper loading. This trend is followed up to 20 wt% copper loading on SiO2. At 30 wt% of copper loading both the active Cu metal surface area and rate of formation of HCALD show down fall due to increase in copper particle sizes. The active Cu metal surface area of various supported Cu catalysts was correlated with their catalytic activity and presented in Fig. 4 . 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst exhibits the highest active metal surface area (6.1 m2. g−1 cat) and the highest rate of formation of HCALD (167.82 μmol.g−1.s−1) in the series. 20Cu/ZrO2 exhibits the lowest rate of formation of HCLAD and 20Cu/MgO exhibits the lowest active metal surface area in the series. The rate of formation of a product over a catalyst represents the activity of the all the active sites present in that catalyst. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst with more number of active sites possesses high copper metal surface area which in turn showed high rate of formation. However, 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited lower rate than 20Cu/MgO even though 20Cu/ZrO2 has higher active metal surface area than 20Cu/MgO catalyst. In addition, 20Cu/ZrO2 (4.6 m2. g−1 cat) and 10Cu/SiO2 (4.7 m2. g−1 cat) (Fig.ES4) have similar active metal surface areas but the rate of formation of HCALD over 10Cu/SiO2 (123.37 μmol.g−1.s−1) is nearly two fold higher than 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst (58.34 μmol.g−1.s−1). These results suggested that the chemo selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD over supported Cu catalysts is not only dependent on the active copper metal surface of the catalysts but also the nature of support which is responsible for the selectivity of the product. The acidity of the supported copper catalysts was evaluated by temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) which allows to assess strength and amount of surface acidic sites presented in the catalysts and the corresponding profiles were depicted in Fig. 5 . Based on the temperature at which adsorbed NH3 molecules tend to desorb, the surface acidic sites are organized as weak (<300 °C), moderate (300–500 °C) and strong (>500 °C) [42]. 20Cu/Al2O3 catalyst shows a broad desorption peak in NH3-TPD profile represents presence of wide range of acidic sites. It indicates 20Cu/Al2O3 catalyst possesses a majority of weak acidic sites along with moderate and strong acidic sites. Despite of MgO is basic 20Cu/MgO catalyst possesses a little amount of moderate acidity. 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst shows two desorption peaks at 464 °C and 582 °C. The small desorption peak at 464 °C represents small amount of moderate acidic sites and the high temperature desorption peak at 582 °C demonstrates existence of major amount of strong acidic sites in 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst shows a desorption peak in temperature region of 200–400 °C which indicates 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst contains weak acidic sites. The basicity of supported copper catalysts is investigated temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) and the respective profiles were presented in Fig. 6 .The CO2-TPD profile of 20Cu/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits desorption peaks in temperature region 150–380 °C indicating weak and moderate basic sites. 20Cu/MgO catalyst is displaying a major desorption peaks at 328 °C along with other small desorption peaks. 20Cu/MgO catalyst contains all the three types of basic sites with high population of weak basic sites. There is no significant desorption peak is observed for 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst. The CO2-TPD profile of 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits a desorption peak at high temperature ∼588 °C which represents existence of strong basic sites in 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. The number of basic sites is higher in the case of 20Cu/MgO catalyst compared to other catalysts. The nature of support in supported metal catalysts is influential in determining the catalytic activity and selectivity. The catalytic activity and selectivity of the supported Cu catalysts in chemo selective hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD is correlated with the surface acidity and basicity of the catalysts and presented in Fig. 7 . All the supported Cu catalysts exhibit more than 80% conversion of CALD irrespective of surface acidity and basicity but a diverse selectivity pattern of HCALD is noticed. It clearly demonstrates the influence of surface acidic and basic sites on product selectivity. CALD consists of two unsaturated functional groups CC and CO so the hydrogenation is feasible in either of the bonds or both also (as shown in Scheme 1). The surface acidity and basicity directs the mode of adsorption of CALD over supported Cu catalysts. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst with a little amount of weak acidic sites, CALD is adsorbed in a direction to reduce only CC bond without disturbing CO of CALD which results selective formation of HCALD. While in other supported Cu catalysts having basicity and acidity there is a competitive adsorption between CO and CC bonds. During this competition, exclusive hydrogenation of CC bond forms HCALD, exclusive hydrogenation of CO forms CAOL and hydrogenation of both bonds forms hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCAOL). MgO supported Cu catalyst with basic sites exhibits 53.51 and 28.38% selectivity’s to HCALD and CAOL respectively. Along with these products, allyl benzene (AB) and other condensation products are also formed. AB is dehydration product of HCAOL (as shown in Scheme 1) which supports the formation of HCAOL by hydrogenation of both the bonds. ZrO2 supported Cu catalyst has both strong acidic and basic sites. 20Cu/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits 43.46, 6.65 and 49.89% selectivity’s to HCALD, CAOL and propyl benzene (PB) respectively. 20Cu/ZrO2 promotes hydrogenation of CO in equal proportion to CC bond and formed CAOL is further hydrogenated to HCAOL. The presence of strong acidic sites in 20Cu/ZrO2 favors hydrogenolysis of HCAOL to propyl benzene (PB). Al2O3 supported Cu catalyst has both weak acidic and basic sites also show a drop in selectivity to HCALD. From these results it could be supposed that the selectivity to HCALD via chemo selective transfer hydrogenation is strongly dependent on nature of support in supported Cu catalysts. The influence of reaction temperature on chemo selective transfer hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD is examined over 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst and the results were presented in Fig. 8 . The study was done at temperature ranging from 260 °C (near to the boiling point of CALD) to 305 °C. The formation of diverse products at different reaction temperatures witnessed the influence of reaction temperature on the titled reaction. At a reaction temperature of 260 °C, complete conversion of CALD is obtained with 100% selectivity to HCALD. With increase in reaction temperature to 275 °C, complete conversion of CALD is achieved while the selectivity to HCALD is decreased to 89%. As long as the reaction temperature increases the selectivity to HCALD is decreasing. At 305 °C, the least selectivity to HCALD 51% is obtained. The raise in reaction temperature beyond 260 °C results the formation of HCAOL, AB and PB at the expense of HCALD selectivity. The raise in reaction temperature may activate the some of the formed HCALD molecules to participate in further hydrogenation of its CO bond to produce HCAOL. Once the HCAOL is formed the acidity of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is enough to perform hydrogenolysis and dehydration reactions which produce PB and AB, respectively. Hence it could be suggested that the optimum reaction temperature for this reaction under these reaction conditions is 260 °C. The effect of amount of feed on catalytic performance of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is examined and the results were presented in Fig. 9 . At WHSV (Weight Hourly Space Velocity) of 1 h−1, complete conversion of CALD is observed with 100% selectivity to HALD at1 h. With increase in WHSV the conversion of CALD as well as selectivity to HCALD are gradually decreased. At WHSH of 2 h−1, the conversion of CALD is decreased to 94% and reaches a minimum of 58% at WHSV of 4 h−1. The high conversion at low WHSV is due to the reactant makes direct contact with the catalyst surface where the number of reactant molecules per active site is low. The decrease in activity with increase in WHSV is may be due to the decrease in residence time of reactant molecules over the catalyst active sites. The effect of mole ratio of CALD to isopropanol on catalytic performance of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst in chemo selective transfer hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD is studied and results were presented in Fig. 10 . The conversion of CALD is increased with increase in moles of isopropanol whereas the selectivity to HCALD is same in all the cases. At a molar ratio of 1:10 and 1:15, the conversions of CALD are 32 and 73% respectively. With increase in mole ratio to 1:20 complete conversion of CALD takes place. Further increase in mole ratio doesn’t influence the conversion of CALD and selectivity to HCALD. From these results it could be suggested that, maximum conversion of CALD and selectivity is achieved at molar ratio of 1:20 under these reaction conditions. Under these reaction parameters, the influence of methanol and ethanol instead of isopropanol was studied. With methanol the conversion of CALD is 79% and the selectivity to HCALD is 78.2%. With ethanol the conversion of CALD is 85% and the selectivity to HCALD is 86.6%. Among the investigated H-donors, isopropanol exhibited selective formation of HCALD in gas phase transfer hydrogenation of CALD. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is subjected to time-on-stream study (TOS) for chemo selective transfer hydrogenation of CALD to HCALD and results were presented in Fig. 11 . It shows that the yield of HCALD is declined during time-on-stream study. The selectivity to HCALD is constant at 100% during the course of reaction while the conversion of CALD is decreased. The fresh and spent 20Cu/SiO2 catalysts were analyzed by TEM and the respective images and particle size distributions were depicted in Fig. 12 . From TEM images and particle size distributions, it can be observed that the mean copper particle size in spent 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is increased from 21.6 nm (fresh 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst) to 28.4 nm. The decline in the catalytic activity of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is due to increase in the copper particles size due to agglomeration. To further investigate the present protocol on exclusive hydrogenation of C = C in α, β unsaturated carbonyl compounds, various α, β unsaturated carbonyl compounds like cyclohexenone, isophorone and crotonaldehyde are tested at reaction temperatures 180, 220 and 110 °C respectively. The selective hydrogenation of C = C in Cyclohexenone yields cyclohexanone. The yield of cyclohexanone is decreased from 100% to 73% during 6 h TOS. The selective hydrogenation of C = C in isophorone and crotonaldehyde yield 3, 3, 5-trimethylcyclohexanone and butyraldehyde respectively. The yield of 3, 3, 5-trimethylcyclohexanone and butyraldehyde are decreasing from 96 to 68% and 99 to 51% respectively. In all the cases the conversion of unsaturated carbonyl compound is decreased and selectivity to saturated carbonyl compound is constant during the TOS. It shows the superiority of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst in gas phase selective transfer hydrogenation of C = C in α, β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds to saturated carbonyl compounds. Based on the results a probable reaction mechanism is proposed and presented in Fig. 13 . In all the supported Cu catalysts, the first step is the dehydrogenation of isopropanol over copper metallic sites to produce hydrogen [43]. In 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst, CALD is adsorbed on Cu metallic sites only in a direction to reduce thermodynamically favorable CC bond and produce selectively HCALD. In other words, the hydrogen available over Cu metallic sites is capable only to reduce CC bond. Hence 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst delivers selective hydrogenation of CC to produce HCALD. In other supported copper catalysts (MgO, Al2O3 and ZrO2), in addition to adsorption of CC bond in CALD, the presence of basic sites promote the adsorption of CO bond in CALD. Consequently, HCALD and CAOL are respectively formed. The formation products AB and PB demonstrated the further hydrogenation of HCALD and CAOL to HCAOL. The catalytic performance of 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is compared with the reported catalytic systems for conversion of CALD to HCALD in Table 3 . Most of the reported catalytic systems comprised of expensive noble metal (Pd and Pt) based catalysts, high H2 pressure operations and need of catalyst separations. The present catalytic system offers noble metal free 20Cu/SiO2catalyst and atmospheric N2 flow in continuous operation which enables no need of catalyst separation steps. Conclusions Various metal oxide supported Cu (Cu/MO, MO = SiO2, MgO, Al2O3 and ZrO2) catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method and applied for selective transfer hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde to hydrocinnamaldehyde with isopropanol as H-donor at atmospheric pressure. All the supported copper catalysts were found to be active for production of hydrocinnamaldehyde. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst exhibited the best results in terms of conversion of cinnamaldehyde and selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde due to the presence of higher number of active copper species. The conversion of cinnamaldehyde was found to be dependent on the active copper metal surface area and the selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde was dependent on the surface acidity and basicity of the catalyst. The exclusive adsorption of CC bond of cinnamaldehyde over Cu/SiO2 catalyst produced complete selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde. Along with CC bond, CO bond adsorption in other supported copper catalysts resulted formation of other products at the expense of hydrocinnamaldehyde. 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst is also efficient in converting cyclohexenone, isophorone and crotonaldehyde into corresponding saturated carbonyl compounds. coredata.dc:description: This work aims to produce hydrocinnamaldehyde via selective CC bond hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde via transfer hydrogenation catalyzed by supported Cu catalysts. The catalytic activity and characterization results demonstrated that conversion of cinnamaldehyde and selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde is an integrated result of active Cu metal surface area and nature of support material. In the case of Cu/SiO2 catalysts, the rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde was linearly dependent on the active Cu metal surface area. A maximum rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde 167.82 μmol.g−1.s-1 was obtained at an active Cu metal surface area of 6.1 m2.gcat -1 over 20 wt. % Cu/SiO2 catalyst. While in the case of other supported Cu catalysts (Cu/MgO, Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/γ-Al2O3) along with the active Cu metal surface area, the surface acidity and basicity governed the selectivity of hydrocinnamaldehyde. The rate of formation of hydrocinnamaldehyde followed the trend Cu/SiO2 >Cu/Al2O3 >Cu/MgO > Cu/ZrO2. Unlike Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the competitive adsorption of CC and CO bonds over these (Al2O3, MgO and ZrO2) supported Cu catalysts altered the selectivity of hydrocinnamaldehyde. Cu/SiO2 catalyst was superior in selective CC hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds via transfer hydrogenation. Cyclohexenone, isophorone and crotonaldehyde were selectively converted into their saturated carbonyl compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Gas phase transfer hydrogenation of α, β- unsaturated carbonyl compounds into saturated carbonyl compounds over supported Cu catalysts
